So

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think that's a real challenge actually linking the laboratory work to translating it to to uh uh population level inferences is is is a huge, huge challenge.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Exactly. Yeah. Uh it's it's it's kind of like a a multi center program type challenge uh where you have multiple different streams of data that might be able to come together for it. Yeah, it's really tough.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I have collaborators uh that have been working on influenza for years and and they'll identify a mutation and say, hey, we found this mutation, uh it's going to cause uh increased risk uh in uh of for for jumping into humans, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And then we screen the population, we say, well that mutation is all over and it's found in in uh all these different lineages and none of them are actually jumping into humans. The ones that are don't even have that mutation. So like translating and understanding what those individual lab experiments mean is hugely challenging, hugely challenging.

meeting_annotations.transcript: So

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dana Mitzel
meeting_annotations.transcript: So at least going to the genetics and a little bit of what you're talking about, I know with us uh with riff, we are trying to do some studies where we infect mosquitoes um with Rift Valley that we isolated preferably from serum from an infected sheep sheep, but it was all lab based studies and then we will feed those mosquitoes on sheep to see the infection on them. But we also take the virus that we initially infected the mosquitoes, what we got out of the mosquitoes, what we're getting out of sheep just to see how the population changes because the population will change based off the host a little bit to where there might be a little bit more bottleneck in the insects versus in the sheep and you might get a little bit more diversity coming out of the sheep.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dana Mitzel
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um so especially when you talk about these vector born viruses, it does get a little bit more difficult because it's all based off of it can be based off of not only it being in the mosquito, but what species of mosquito and then what is it feeding on, which you know, is it feeding on a sheep versus a pig versus a cow and even those species can change a little bit. So and we do also try to do this a little bit in cells because we do have sheep cells or mosquito cells, um some wildlife cells so we can try to um passage them in cells and you know, one of our goals eventually will be to say, okay, if we passage these in the cells, you know, how much different is it from when we actually passage it in the vectors and the animals because let's face it the cell work is a lot easier, but is it is it going to give us similar results that we see in the actual host and vectors?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, vector born pathogens really really challenge my brain. Um you know, you have the viral particle and then you have an infected vector and then you have another host. So the virus has to be competent to replicate in all these different cell types that are very divergent.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh from I I have a a question for you. Um because you you mentioned you do uh viral discovery uh what what sort of

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl (UGA)

meeting_annotations.speaker: Efrim Lim, ASU
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um so we're mostly interested in human um cases. So for example, um someone has fever, but we don't quite know why or um you know, um the more recent COVID thing, you know, when people had respiratory symptoms initially and early last year, we screen them for flu first and if they're flu negative, then we tested for COVID. So it's kind of the idea of like there's something else causing this. And so we then use next generation sequencing to just sequence unbiasedly the samples and then look for viral sequences from there. Um then sometimes we find a new virus, sometimes a known virus with a different mutation, that sort of thing.
